remarks: Principle of transitive induction, finite and non-class version.  The first three hypotheses give various existences, the next three give necessary substitutions and the last two are the basis and the induction hypothesis.  (Contributed by Drahflow, 12-Nov-2015.)  (Revised by RP, 30-May-2020.)
statement:
relexpindlem.1 $e |- ( et -> Rel R ) $.
relexpindlem.2 $e |- ( et -> R e. _V ) $.
relexpindlem.3 $e |- ( et -> S e. _V ) $.
relexpindlem.4 $e |- ( i = S -> ( ph <-> ch ) ) $.
relexpindlem.5 $e |- ( i = x -> ( ph <-> ps ) ) $.
relexpindlem.6 $e |- ( i = j -> ( ph <-> th ) ) $.
relexpindlem.7 $e |- ( et -> ch ) $.
relexpindlem.8 $e |- ( et -> ( j R x -> ( th -> ps ) ) ) $.
relexpindlem $p |- ( et -> ( n e. NN0 -> ( S ( R ^r n ) x -> ps ) ) ) $.
$d R i j x $.
$d S i j x $.
$d ch i $.
$d et i j x $.
$d i j ps $.
$d i th $.
$d j ph x $.
$d n x $.
